content:
3, 2015
												Talisman: Digital edition is a game I had never heard of before this free weekend.  I immediately liked the game.  This Talisman: DE is a digital Board game, literally.  You play as a variety of classes trying to buff your stats and make it to the center of the board before anyone else gets there.  The game relies heavily on RNG type randomness, Most actions involve dice rolls, and most "encounters" rely on the way the deck is "shuffled".  Another thing to note, I don't know if I'm just unlucky, but this game is long, I have been in the same game for about 4 hours now. no one has come very close to winning yet. I don't know how long the average game against the ai lasts, but mine are always terribly long.   Overall though I like the gameplay and art a lot. The art reminds me of classic Dungeons and Dragons art, and less grimdark games workshop art. I recommend this to anyone still interested after all that. I dont know  what kind of player will like it most really. If you get it, I hope you have fun!

content:
, 2014
												I love a great boardgame but let's face it, these "cardboard children" - to borrow a line from RPS - can take a LOT of table real estate to play. Talisman is a massive game in its "analog form" and with all of the expansions and four players, the setup is considerable and games can be marathons. But that's all good as boardgamers expect that. That said, Talisman Digital Edition fots nicely on my PC, requires mere minutes at most of setup an most importantly, captures the sheer fun of Talisman, Isn't that why we play games, for fun?A few negative reviews commented on the woeful AI. But, perhaps these folk are playing the prelude titled Talisman: Prologue. I have found the AI to be pretty good. And let's not forget that Talisman is largely a luck based game. All of the so-called tactics I have seen and heard about the game must still bow to the capriciousness of the deity known as RNG; even an AI like Deep Blue cannot predict the vagaries of dice rolls.There are a few issues that linger. One of the most annoying is when an AI opponent draws an event card. Unless you are a speed reader or you know every Talisman card by rote - and with all of the expansions in the physical boardgame there is an insane number of cards, you won't have time to read what the event is. You have to zoom in on the board section where the event is. The same holds true for other non-spell cards. This has been brought up to the devs but as yet there has been no fix for this.The digital version allows you to earn runes which grant advatages in gameplay. [AI also collects these as well]. I like the mechanic as it lends a sort of leveling up feeling.The Dungeon Expansion is next up and I cannot wait for its release! If it is as faithful as the physical version of the game, it's going to be a blast.I think that Talisman Digital Edition is a wonderful introduction to the fun world of tabletop boardgaming and it scratches the itch of tabletop boardgamers who want to play without the crazy setup and rather forced solo variants for the physical game found round the interwebz.This is a STEAL at the price and I would advise buyers to spend a little extra dosh and get The Reaper and Frostmarch expansions as they add considerably to the game.I hope that more boardgames experience a digital conversion. Are you listening Games Workshop and Fantasy Flight?EDIT: 18 November. The Dungeon expansion really ramps this game up considerably. The AI can be quite nasty and that's good as Talisman is a cut throat game. I am hopeful that the devs will release Blood Moon and The Dragon next. These two expansions literally change the game, adding a bit more unpredictability to a game that can punch you in the face already and have you smiling about it.UPDATE January 15: Ya gota love this developer. With the latest update there are two new free characters. These two are not even present in the physical boardgame but were last seen in the 1986(!) version of Talisman. More achievements plus what seems to be a hint that the Highland expansion is next! This is very cool as it is a one of the big corner expansions!!

content:
er 19, 2015
												It’s unfortunate but Talisman is regrettably too feature starved to recommend.And it’s not the expansions being individually sold, as that’s how the tabletop game is presented – it’s the awful connection issues, the inability to save an online game (you can resume the last game played online and those who played may reconnect, but that limits you to one game on the go), the bare minimum of the interface being explained (Counterspell must be queued up – ie; cast before the spell you’d like to prevent – because…because I don’t know) and the like.  Players can’t view the board spaces and the cards on it on another players turn.  And the AI (which can be played with in a multiplayer game to add players to the game) isn’t really competitive.  It doesn’t try to “win” the game.Now, the good is it’s pretty faithful to the boardgame, and when it works and everyone remains connected it’s a pretty good way to scratch that itch. But the constant interruptions just drag the game on. It's a shame.

												A beautiful, well-designed, well-engineered video game adaptation of an absolutely godawful board game.Talisman is one of those games that people keep playing not on its own merits (it's about as strategic as Crazy Eights and takes HOURS for a game) but because of the nostalgia filter.If you have fond memories of this game from your childhood or early gaming days, then this is an excellent way to play online with added computer opponents. If you don't, then I recommend grabbing a deck of cards and playing War. At least it's over faster.

content:
3, 2015
												Its monoply with combat and no free parking.This is a digital version of the board game.  You and your opponets roll a dice pick a direction and move that many spaces then draw an encounter card.  some times its helpful but most of the time it screws you over.  Theres also combat where you roll a dice and what your fighting rolls a dice and you add your strength to the dice.  you lose and you lose a life you win you get to keep them as torphy. get enough trophies and you can up your strenght or craft.  and thats really it. your trying to beef your guy up enough to surive the spaces in the center of the board. its long and boring.  the avrage game runs about an hour per player.  you do get a number of characters to choose from each with there own advantages but some are way better than others.  (the assassin is way OP).  you can unlock runes that give you the option of starting with buffs which can speed future games along but its still the same boring game.on top of that the UI isn't great.  trying to use a card in your inventory is needlessly complicated and spells are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to use.  most of the time you have to queue them a turn ahead of time and then the game auto casts them at the soonest legal moment next turn and there is no way to back out once you've decided to start doing somthing.  there are also things that are suppose to give you the choice of uping  either strength or craft but the game will auto pick which ever stat is highest.  So we have a slow boring game with a dodgey UI.  Pass

content:
ber 21, 2015
												Gave up in disgust.  The devs for this game had two jobs:1:  Design a AI for solo play.2:  Design a UI that allows players to play an already existing board game on the PC.The devs failed so spectacularly at #2 that playing a game I loved became an exercise in frustration.  I am not exaggerating when I say that making this game a browser/mobile game would have been an improvement, as the developers would be forced to conform to standard UI conventions.  For example, nstead of Enter to accept prompts, the keybind is Space.. what?  Why can't I exit out of my active window with Escape?  Why does it always send me to the Main Menu?  And of course, I can't change the keybinds!  Borderless Windowed Mode?  Lol.  Run in higher resolution?  HAHAHAHA.When I say that the devs had two jobs, I mean it - all art assets are lifted from the board game in 2D format.  The Help function directs players to their site with a wonky search function.  Nothing like seeing format code while browsing the site with Firefox.  Real quality, that.  All of this makes enduring the awful UI especially galling.  I'm done with this game.

												I recommend the digital implementation of this game over the board game, but I do not recommend Talisman over other digital board games.Odds are good that, if you're looking at buying the Digital Edition, you know what Talisman is all about. As a board game, I don't think it is very good. But, I do think that this digital implementation makes it playable. So, if you know you want to play Talisman, this is the way to go. If you're thinking about getting this because it's a much cheaper way to explore the board game, this is the way to go.If you've stumbled across this game and you're hoping for a really enjoyable experience and you don't know what you're getting into, you probably will not enjoy this game.

												If you want a games night with a few of your friends this is the game for you. If you are looking for a solo experience this game is probably not for you.To get the most out of it i would recommend changing the game from focusing on the Crown of Command, to killing the Lord of Darkness, which will require some DLC, but it is worth it. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 18, 2015
												As a little boy I was always curious about the Talisman boardgame. Now it came to Steam and on a sale I took my chances. Pros: + Great art & figures just like the boardgame.+ Long game time (depends how you look at it)+ Various characters to choose from, each with their own special skill(s)+ Some interessing items, followers & spells to get or sites to visitCons:- To much depends on the lucky dice rolls- Because of the dice rolls, the game can drag on and on, even if you have the Staff of Command- Long game time (depends how you look at it)- Imbalances on character front. A thief has 100% chance to Steal from you, even if you are the most powerful character on the board. It would be more interessing and more fair that the victim is able to save and hurt the thief when caught. Same for a sorceress with Beguile.- Did I already say it depends to much on the lucky dice rolls?Personally, I enjoyed it first but later on the myriad of (un)lucky dice rolls, character imbalances & to long game times diminished my enjoyment rapidly. I would rather spend my time on other games where I have much more controle at the games progress - and I have to blame my own stupidity - than on the sheer luck of a dice roll.If they do some tweaking to give your chosen character a fairer chance/saving roll against some odds, I might take another look at it and change my mind about it . . .

												Steam really needs a thumb sideways for games like this.On one hand the game seems to be a faithful adaptation to the board game (from what people say. Ive never played it) The game is realativly fun and it has an online option.The other hand though.... I encountered a slew of bugs/glitches which ended in some actions not being counted or moves being skipped. The AI is horrible. They refuse to go into the inner section until they are around 13 in their stat and they make a lot of stupid moves. A mectric ton of dlc that kind of feels like its to much when the base game has very little to offer in terms of chracters/boards/and cards.If you like the board game and want to play it then im sure you'll have a decent time with it. For everyone else though, I would avoid buying this unless its very cheap or on a humble bundle.

11, 2015
												Steam really needs a thumb sideways for games like this.On one hand the game seems to be a faithful adaptation to the board game (from what people say. Ive never played it) The game is realativly fun and it has an online option.The other hand though.... I encountered a slew of bugs/glitches which ended in some actions not being counted or moves being skipped. The AI is horrible. They refuse to go into the inner section until they are around 13 in their stat and they make a lot of stupid moves. A mectric ton of dlc that kind of feels like its to much when the base game has very little to offer in terms of chracters/boards/and cards.If you like the board game and want to play it then im sure you'll have a decent time with it. For everyone else though, I would avoid buying this unless its very cheap or on a humble bundle.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												Although I never played the board game, I can easily attest to the fact that this game brings the worst out in yourself and your friends, which in itself leads to hilarious and memorable moments. That, coupled with the random nature of the game, is in my opinion its greatest strength, as it allows everybody to compete on an even level. The randomness might get frustrating in single player though and I clearly recommend that you band together and buy the four pack, so you have somebody to play with, because the social aspect of the game is half the experience.On the downside, the technical aspect of multiplayer matches does have some hiccups. I have experienced sync issues and game crashes a couple of times, which is aggravating when you are about to wrap up a game session, which easily runs in at about two hours. This shouldn’t keep you from buying the game if you have some friends around to play it with though.

content:
6, 2014
												Almost identcal to playing the board game with a few major exceptions. the most important being speed. A real life Talisman game can usually take up 6hrs. With the turn speed for the PC ramped up to 10 I finished my first game in 3hrs.  This is not a problem as playing well in games causes you to level up unlocking new stuff. Quite what I'm not yet sure as it will take more than one game to level up. The other major difference is price. A full set of Talisman with the expnasion will srt you back nearly £100 for the physical version.I do love my physichal set and this does lack the atmosphere of having some like minded mates round for a good boardgames session. But as an introduction to the game or as a way of killing the hours over the summer while your mates are on holiday this is highly recomended. Also if you have friends who play but dont live locally it is also possible to set up an online game over the web.

content:
er 26, 2015
												After taking 2 hours to learn the game with a couple playthroughs, we set up for a final game of the night. Rolling Thief, a few drinks in, I decide to fully immerse myself for this playthrough and give it an honest try. The adventure began, and McStickyfingers was unleashed upon the world. Turn one, McStickyfingers immediately heads to town and run into the Black Market. What a perfect way to get a head start, he thought, and jumps at the opportunity to pay 1 gold for a full suit of plate mail. Being the most obnoxious and unsubtle Thief in the land, McSticky is caught and hauled off to Jail to reflect on his life choices. Seven turns in, the world around him is passing by, with another filthy bandit behind bars. A wanted poster for anti-thievery is picked up by a travelling Pirate, passing through town. Ironically, the Pirate ceases his own mischief and pledges to ensure McSticky remains off the streets. "There is only room for one bandit, here!" - He thought. McStickyfingers is finally released from Jail on the eighth turn. Has he changed? Did he learn his lesson? You may ask him. In turn he would respond to you with a question, "Are you kidding?" Upon release, McStickyfingers immediately runs into the Pirate and steals the wanted poster of himself right out of Pirate's hands. The world is surely doomed, now.Many turns go by, which means many items are stolen from anyone and anything. A collection of swords is made within' McStickyfingers' inventory - one from every player leaving each of them unarmed. It isn't long before Death himself is unanimously tasked to put a stop to the McStickyfinger shenanigans. Fumbling around with his shiny swords, McSticky is caught from behind and beheaded with one stroke of the scythe. Was this the end? No. More like ...are you kidding? At the end of Mr. Grim's action, McStickyfingers is revived and immediately re-gathers his belongings before anyone else can act. It seems not even Death can stop the reign of McStickyfingers' mischief. It isn't long before deals are made from the other adventurers to our beloved Thief to spare their inventory from his sticky fingers. Gold is thrown in his direction from every which way.Having never given up on his quest, wanted poster or not, the Pirate is behind the scenes with an anti-theft bag to stash his belongings. Arming to the teeth, a rivalry is born. To be continued...10/10 would go on epic thieving heists again.

content:
er 26, 2015
												I played the Talisman board game with my old gaming group and we would have hours of fun taking us into the wee hours of the morning without even realizing it. This game brings all that fun back, but with the option to save and quit when the sun starts peeking through the windows and you need to hide away for a few hours.However, it does feel like there are still some bugs to work out, such as abilities that can be activated 'at will' don't seem to be available to use when the 'at will' need arises. This may be a bug or I am missing the prompts to give me that opportunity. The only other downside I can see is you are not physically sitting at the table with your friends as you play to toss around the smack talk and make deals on the fly to take a problematic character down.All in all, this is a fantastically fun game to play and all of the expansions are more than worth it for the added content and additional characters. You would be amazed to see a Courtesan beating the heck out of a Dread Knight when things go in your favor.Definitely worth your time and money and everything goes on sale with some frequency. The standalone characters are also worth it if you grab them on sale. Otherwise you'll have plenty of others to play with un til they do.

content:
er 29, 2014
												This is a good and solid game.Lots of replay value, interesting character traits make for well varied characters.There are quit a few items and encounters in the game as well, every game has a unique feel to it.Unfortunately there are also some problems.Some characters seem overpowered while others seem quite weak.The object of the game is to get to the crown of command, cast the command spell, and do 1 damage to each player if you roll a 4 or higher.This works great in theory.In practice however, you will find yourself sitting on the crowd of command, casting the spell over and over, while the rest of the players have plenty of time to heal and keep about their business.Even though you are a lot stronger than all the others this process can take a very long time.Leaving you sitting there turn after turn doing nothing but casting that spell until finally you get lucky and the others can not heal fast enough.This can take a very... very long time.You could kill the players individually, but they seem to respawn after a few turns. So the chances of winning the game that way seem pretty slim.All in all i would say this is a good game and worth buying.But it needs some finetuning to make it a great game.

content:
er 26, 2015
												I played the Talisman board game with my old gaming group and we would have hours of fun taking us into the wee hours of the morning without even realizing it. This game brings all that fun back, but with the option to save and quit when the sun starts peeking through the windows and you need to hide away for a few hours.However, it does feel like there are still some bugs to work out, such as abilities that can be activated 'at will' don't seem to be available to use when the 'at will' need arises. This may be a bug or I am missing the prompts to give me that opportunity. The only other downside I can see is you are not physically sitting at the table with your friends as you play to toss around the smack talk and make deals on the fly to take a problematic character down.All in all, this is a fantastically fun game to play and all of the expansions are more than worth it for the added content and additional characters. You would be amazed to see a Courtesan beating the heck out of a Dread Knight when things go in your favor.Definitely worth your time and money and everything goes on sale with some frequency. The standalone characters are also worth it if you grab them on sale. Otherwise you'll have plenty of others to play with un til they do.

content:
er 29, 2014
												This is a good and solid game.Lots of replay value, interesting character traits make for well varied characters.There are quit a few items and encounters in the game as well, every game has a unique feel to it.Unfortunately there are also some problems.Some characters seem overpowered while others seem quite weak.The object of the game is to get to the crown of command, cast the command spell, and do 1 damage to each player if you roll a 4 or higher.This works great in theory.In practice however, you will find yourself sitting on the crowd of command, casting the spell over and over, while the rest of the players have plenty of time to heal and keep about their business.Even though you are a lot stronger than all the others this process can take a very long time.Leaving you sitting there turn after turn doing nothing but casting that spell until finally you get lucky and the others can not heal fast enough.This can take a very... very long time.You could kill the players individually, but they seem to respawn after a few turns. So the chances of winning the game that way seem pretty slim.All in all i would say this is a good game and worth buying.But it needs some finetuning to make it a great game.

content:
y 15, 2016
												Pay no mind to the Metacritic score, those critics reviewed the game when it first came out.  At that time it had a huge number of bugs and other problems, particularly with multiplayer, but those have been entirely rectified.  This is a fantastic adaptation of a great board game.  It takes a long time to play, especially with a lot of players; less time than the actual board game though since you don't have to bother with setting it up or putting it away.  The game itself is quite a lot of fun for any RPG and board game lover.  It's a great value too, especially if you pick it up on sale (and it goes on sale fairly frequently).  The only real downside is that the AI is still terrible, so you're pretty much limited to playing with friends for a worthwhile experience.

content:
2015
												Talisman: Digital Edition is a fun time killer if you have nothing to do for a hour or so.  It's convenient if you just want to relax, play a quick single player game and move onto to other things you need to do that afternoon.  There's plemty of expansions and alot of characters to choose from that keeps it interesting.On the downside, however, the game does have its flaws.    Spells not working when casted/que'd. Picking targets for spells sometimes doesn't work properly or is confusing.     Some cards don't work occasionally like, "Use this card before another players turn" where you'll try to use it but nothing happens and you just get a "dismiss" option only.   And my personal complaint is the computer player almost always rolls a "6"  and you'll get ten "1's" in a row which can be frustrating.Overall, it's still a fun game to play if you look past the flaws.   Catch it on sale.   Highly recommend getting the expansions (Dungeon, Highlands, etc) for it as well as it adds another level to the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2015
												I'm not a fan of Games Workshop.  In fact, I don't like Games Workshop at all.  But this review is not about the company, but about this game.  I played Talisman when it first came out.  When I found out it was on Steam, I was intrigued.  When I picked it up with the Humble Bundle, I was interested in giving it a shot.I enjoy the game.  I enjoy running around the board, gathering power, and making a push for the crown, leaving everyone in my dust.  Yes, the game begins fairly random, but there is a strategy to the game, and if you know what you're doing, the game becomes less and less random as you shape your character into the champion (or horror) you want it to be.Some simple tactics:  1)  Get to the Warlock and try to get the Clockwork Owl as quickly as you can.  This turns your die rolls for movement into something you can control (since you can move your die roll or less after this).  2)  Get to the warlock and get the bag of holding.  Having 8 concealable slots to carry your most precious gear in is a good thing.  3)  Go to the warlock and get the orb of prophesy (or be lucky and draw the magic item which does similar).  This allows you to control your encounters.  Along the way you should be getting magic items or followers to pad out your abilities.  But once you have those three items (or heck, even just the first), you're able to control your fate fairly well, and can make the push to get to the middle of the board and win.The introduction of runestones is an interesting twist, as is having fate points.  Those both help to deter getting hosed early in the game, and I think they're a workable addition.  I plan on picking up the expansions.I give the Digital Edition of Talisman 4/5.

												Talisman takes its place as my number two favorite board game style video game of all time. The first place spot goes to Dokapon Kingdom but that is another thing in of its self.Talisman's gameplay is solid and, up until the addition of the house rules setting, the end game could get very boring and repetitive. The game allows you to play with many different playstyles and allows unique experiences every time you play. You always need to be aware of what other players are doing or you may just end up finding them on their way to the end while you are still making your way there.I do not care for the idea behind all of the new characters being their own idividual DLC, it seems to be a little over the top for me, especially with how little each new character actually adds to the game. 												An excellent board game from ancient times.  It requires patience and cunning.  You gain strength or craft to become strong enough to fight your way to the crown of command.  If you like a meaty 2 hour plus length of game, then this is for you.  The game can be sped up with various options.  It is enhanced with several expansions. I can't wait to try online version!

content:
17, 2014
												Talisman: Digital Edition is a faithful update to the old school Games-Workshop Talisman board game.  The game is actually based on a newer iteration by Fantasy Flight games however much of the original feel is still there.  The digital implementation of the game features an intuitive interface, crisp artwork, and balance improvements that don’t allow a Chaos Warrior to run rampant across your game board and on top of competing players.  The only real downside is that the AI is not very good and doesn’t try to win the game –however the game plays well in multiplayer and is really a blast.  If you want to play an old school early 1990’s board game online, love games workshop, or just want to turn your buddies into a toad and curb stomp them . . . this game is for you!

content:
0, 2015
												Okay, right off the bat, this is an awesome game to play! So much fun to level up your character, gaining strength and craft to fight enemies with. The object of the game is to reach "the crown of command" in the center of the board. However this is not so simple. You will have to go on different quests throughout the game to gain an object known as a "Talisman" to get the various places on the board. You will need one as you travel from the middle region of the board to the center region. However many things could happen between getting one and getting through to the center region. A player could fight you and kill you. A witch, bear or demon could spawn on you and destroy powerful or useful items you're carrying. The worst? Being turned into a toad. This is where all your items are dropped in the space you have turned into the toad. While playing as a toad, other players can pick up your items. It's a very challenging game and extremely time consuming. The 8 hours i have played.. 6 of them is just one full game of talisman, where unfortunately i did not win! I have the actual board game too and the digital version helped me learn it better as it gives you tutorials on your playthrough. Of course these can be turned off! If you are a fan of fantasy, board games and strategy then this one is definately for you! For what it is, i give it an 8/10. The game itself is excellent, but as i say you need a LOT of time spare if you're wanting to finish a game!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 12, 2015
												Love this game. Love it! I'm a board game/TTRPG junkie (multi-time Gen Con attendee). There's a ton of content here, and the game is fun and challenging at the same time. It's nice to be able to just jump into the digital edition without setup, and even with some AI that's not TOO bad. It does make a few boneheaded mistakes though.For instance I usually play with random characters against 3 AI. I had the Troll. I killed one of the other characters and forgot to loot ALL the items (my own fault, hit the button to quick) and the Devil's Minion CPU player swooped in and grabbed it all including the follower that reduces the Peril of Plane's requirements by 1 die. OMG. The Devil's Minion made to the the Crown of Command, because he made it there so early he only had 5 STR and 6 CRA. I got EXTREMELY lucky and grabbed the poltergiest as a follower on the right side of the outer region of the board. Along there was "The healer with 2 free heals " (thankfully I got turned to Good along the way!) and "The Shrine", next to them was the Forest. So since I could only move one space it was great that I could keep moving back and forth between these spaces healing myself and trying to bump up my craft at the Forest. I also had spells of one Counterspell, one Random, and one Temporal Warp. I was going to use the Temporal Warp when I finally started making my run to the Crown! I made a huge mistake by going into the Village and not realizing it ditched the Poltergiest! OH NO! Since I had 10 STR and 5 CRA, I decided to make a run for it. The Devil's Minion rolled BADLY on quite a few Crown spells. I luckily made my way all the way to the Crown with 11 STR from figting one monster along the way and cashing some in. So the Devil's Minion had 5 lives, I had 4. But I definitely had the upper hand from a mathematical standpoint. So what does the Devil's Minion do when he fights me, he picks STR!! WHAT IN THE. I was afraid it was going to be a race to 0 to see who could roll luck (he COULDN'T beat me in STR 11 vs 5, but he had a chance in CRA 5 vs 6). So I whittled him down to 1 health, and THEN he finally lets loose with a CRA attack and actually wins. I beat him the next turn.This is what I mean by the AI makes some poor decisions. What should have been a nail-biter, ended up being a big WHA? What is he doing?! Still love the game!!

Lots of options for which DLC to use each game and what parts of each can be used.  Know games can take 30 minutes to 3 hours to win.  What character you play and what cards you and the others get make a huge difference in the time involved.

												I can understand why this game might get rated low. Talisman is sort of fundamentally "unfun," especially when played without face to face or voicechat. The multiplayer is significantly buggy, and the autosave system doesn't always work. There are fewer technical problems every patch, though, and there's still a game to be played here. As an adaptation of Talisman, it's perfect: It does what Talisman wants to do. I wouldn't recommend going into it with anyone you can't comfortably have a loosely-contextualized conversation for hours, but it seems absurd to criticize an adaptation of a board game for being like that board game.

												Having grown up on Talisman 2nd Edition, I have grown to appreciate and enjoy 4th Edition. It fixes a lot of issues that were present in 2nd. Starting characters with high craft are no longer at such a steep disadvantage to those of high strength. The inclusion of the fate mechanic can help ever so much with catastrophic dice rolls and, for myself, makes being evil desirable.Digital edition is based off 4th Edition rules and faithfully done so. This game is, as of writing this, still a work in progress, so there are bugs to work out. However, the development team is continuously releasing patches to fix problems and content updates, to include new expansions and characters for those who have bought them.For those who enjoy Talisman, I recommend getting the season pass, which unlocks all content for T:DE in perpetuity. As a fan, it's nice to be able to play without the bothersome setup and clean up (or other players, often).

content:
6, 2015
												A real fun game for you and three buds!!!  You have characters to choose from and they all have special abilities that effect game play. The base game has plenty to choose from so don't worry. Each player begins at a character specific start square on the outer ring on the board. The board is made of three rings of space each with location names on them, some of these locations also have special abilities that effect your pawn. You have 2 sums that are used in combat, strength and craft, then life, fate and gold all of which can be leveled up or chipped away at to reduce them lower that starting amounts.You roll a random generated die and move to the tile options you come up with, than you draw an adventure card that may be a monster, loot, item or event to challenge youor the other players. The object is to level up collecting items boosting your stats and fighting the other players, It plays just like a board game- one player after another takeing turns but as the game goes on the difficulty and struggle increases. You want to get to the center of the board crossing through two "rings" of board tiles to get to the tower where you take control and cast a spell that slowly kills off the other players to win. After a game is finnished you claim XP and level up to the next level where you can get bonuses to the pawn you pick for the next game.WARNING!! The games seem to take a long time to play through, I've played many- finnished two and both of those took longer than 3 hours to play. Lots of fun! Very replayable, lots of laughs with your friends.If you like tabletop games, GAMES WORKSHOP games you should enjoy this one, I got it for 5 bucks on sale but can say it is worth the full price. The game also has lots of DLC in the form of new player characters- ($1.99) each and several boards or expansions... ($5.99)) and up.-Mr. GrAnD

content:
y 23, 2015
												Great Game, so long as your playing with other people.My only three gripes about it would be the AI opponents, Runes, and the online connectivity.The AI is not the greatest. They do some incredibly stupid things, things not even new players would conceivably do. And often with certain characters (Ogre, Necromancer, Ghoul, Minstril to name a few) will not even use the characters abilities at any point in the match. Runes ruin the experience if you use them, and make certain characters blatantly overpowered compared to others. Most people do not use them anyway, so it's not that big an issue, but i just don't see any benefit for them existing.And for online, connections can be a bit shakey at certain times of day, but so far the dev's have been working hard at relieving that issue, and its shown (for me anyway).There are a few other bugs here and there, but they are also being dealth with all the time, and usually don't interfere with a match.A friend of mine has said Hot-Seat Multiplayer also works quite well, so playing with real friends just like you would on the physical version is a plus. If you like board or tabletop games, or decent games to play with friends, pick up Talisman: Digital Edition. The season pass is also worthwhile considering all of the content that is ahead. Overall its one of the better games i've played in the past year or two.

content:
22, 2015
												My first game lasted almost 3 hours, but it worths it!I'm a quick disinterested guy when a game doesn't appeal me, but eh. Pro:+Rules easy to understand: You have to be the last one standing on the iron throne in the middle (ok there's no throne). For that, you must weaken your opponents during the early and mid game, and strenghen yourself killing monsters or training yourself with event cards. Eventhough you can win with luck only, if a dice roll doesn't please you, you can reroll it using one "destiny point" which are limited depending on the character your choose. Because yeah, each characters have their own special ability. +This boarding game is also a RPG, and it's well mixed! +SFX are ok, I didn't have to mute the background music.+Addictive: Because you never know what will happen, you won't stop playing-Con:-The basic board is quite small, eventhough it's easier that way, when I ended my first game I wanted more! -DLC's ... I like the game, but I wonder why I have to pay to have additional content and heroes.-The UI is boring. I wish I could only use my keyboard in the game But... I'm so happy to win over an assassin who was 4x stronger than me, a sorceress who annoyed me the whole time with her spells and a gambler, which is also the hero I chose, who was far worse than me because he didn't know how and when he should have used his destiny points to win. That's why I would recommend this game =D

												I can't judge the game against the old board game as I have never played it.  That being said, the game has a great variety characters, gear and encounters to make your e-board game experience feel like and adventure.On the down side, the game can seem to drag on due to alot of unlucky rolls. 												If you're a fan of boardgames then this is great. It has a lot of different characters and offers quite a lot of gameplay variety, especially if you have the expansion packs. Best to buy the season pass on sale.Gameplay wise, you pick a character, travel around the map battling monsters and completing quests in order to increase your character's strength or craft (magic) score. er 7, 2015
												4 hours in to a game, one turn away from winning, and you get pulled out of the middle and robbed. 3 hours in to a game and your friend turns you in to a frog and kills you. 2 hours in and you're on your 4th character because nothing will go right. You get Talisman'd a lot in this game... why would anyone want to play this? Cause its a heck of a lot of fun. You spend the game raising your strength and craft, the two stats you use to fight battles. Talisman is one big journey to level your character up enough to go challenge whatever is in the middle of the board. Sometimes you might have to fight a boss to win the game, other times you might have to steal everyone's items, or you might even vote to see if the persons worthy. It's the mix of endings, cards, and characters that make the game interesting.I highly recommend playing with actual people, while the computer has decent decision making skills it is far from perfect.

content:
6, 2015
												A real fun game for you and three buds!!!  You have characters to choose from and they all have special abilities that effect game play. The base game has plenty to choose from so don't worry. Each player begins at a character specific start square on the outer ring on the board. The board is made of three rings of space each with location names on them, some of these locations also have special abilities that effect your pawn. You have 2 sums that are used in combat, strength and craft, then life, fate and gold all of which can be leveled up or chipped away at to reduce them lower that starting amounts.You roll a random generated die and move to the tile options you come up with, than you draw an adventure card that may be a monster, loot, item or event to challenge youor the other players. The object is to level up collecting items boosting your stats and fighting the other players, It plays just like a board game- one player after another takeing turns but as the game goes on the difficulty and struggle increases. You want to get to the center of the board crossing through two "rings" of board tiles to get to the tower where you take control and cast a spell that slowly kills off the other players to win. After a game is finnished you claim XP and level up to the next level where you can get bonuses to the pawn you pick for the next game.WARNING!! The games seem to take a long time to play through, I've played many- finnished two and both of those took longer than 3 hours to play. Lots of fun! Very replayable, lots of laughs with your friends.If you like tabletop games, GAMES WORKSHOP games you should enjoy this one, I got it for 5 bucks on sale but can say it is worth the full price. The game also has lots of DLC in the form of new player characters- ($1.99) each and several boards or expansions... ($5.99)) and up.-Mr. GrAnD

content:
ry 24, 2016
												This is a great game, I never heard of Talisman until i saw my friends playing the steam version, and I now play it almost once a week if not more with them. I would reccommend this game to anyone who just wants to have a good time with friends, but if youre looking for good gameplay on your own... unless you really just want some nostalgia This game isn't for you.Pros---------------Good time waster with friends-nostalgic for you long time Talisman players-interesting interactions-you can laugh at the horrible AICons---------------Horribly buggy at times... many of which are game breaking (for example followers or spells that let you choose what your reroll will be will often reroll your second dice if you have 2 to choose from, or if you visit a shop and dont have enough money for an item the game just doesnt know what to do and breaks)-purely based on RNG very few times is decision making or skill going to win you the game because 90% of this game is pure luck unless you get some crazy powerful items from some of the expansions (cough cough clockwork owl) or if you get characters that can see the top of the deck like sage or spy.-kinda already stated as a pro but the AI is horrible, some might see that as a good thing because they can give you good items for bad ones or engage in battles they clearly cant win or dont use some items because they forget to... but otherwise its kinda stupid-DLC for the game can be pretty pricey, if you buy the game and all expansions (not including the standalone characters) currently available it will go for roughly $45 or you can make it $75 and buy the season pass which includes all current and future DLC except one that was sold for charity.TL;DR: The game is great to hang out with friends especially if you cant get together im person easily (or at all) But if you want everything its gonna be quite the money drop, the game is also horribly buggy and seems to lack some quality of life features like cancel buttons for most actions (shopping or spell casting for example) but if you can get past the bugs and horrible AI, then its a good time with your friends guarenteed!

content:
y 27, 2016
												I'm sure that this is a really good game 73% of players have said so plus, I would love to pick up some of the DLC that are on sale this week, I just wish I could play it. Unfortunately, it will only run for about 3- 5 turns then it freezes not the whole PC just the game and I have to ctrl-alt-del out. I am well in excess of the recommended PC specs plus, have tried all the available fixes on the forums here and elsewhere and asked many questions.I reported the problem to Nomad Games however, as there is no crash report generated when it freezes they have very little to work on except my PC specs and my list of tried but failed fixes.Apparently I have logged 2.4 hours play, this is NOT actual play but running the program just to try out various "fixes" .I have tried every fix I can find on line plus, turning off background process or varying game play combinations that I can think of that could be causing the problem, add my research time to find an answer and I must have spent at least 5 hours on this game without actually playing it.Perhaps with the soon expected patch it will finally work for me.I'm very disappointed so far, especially as I will miss out on the current DLC sale, the only consolation for me is that I bought the base game during a previous sale.Why a thumbs up? Well, I can't really not recommend or criticize it because I haven't played it yet plus, the freezing problem seems to be a very rare occurrence for the majority and it would appear that most of those who had the problem found on line answers that unfortunately did not work for me.I will revise this review if I ever get this game to run.UPDATEI have no idea what has changed but, the game has been running without problems for over an hour. I'm still somewhat confused over parts of the gameplay although the tutorial has helped. I guess i'll just have to read the game manual again as well.It looks like this is going to be a fun game based on my experience so far with an understanding of gameplay around say 75% I would give the game at least 7 out of 10 andf I have the feeling that after more playing that score will increase.I originally bought this as a precursor to buying the board game if I enjoyed it and I have a strong feeling that I will be buying the board game as well.

content:
y 29, 2016
												Very happy to have this game on pc.  I still own 2 versions of the original board game which I have played countless times.  As such I can confirm the game rules are superbly accurate to the original, making this game a must for all Talisman fans.On occasion, it can be difficult to use an ability or specific card during your turn (within the time limit given) as the game will not remind or encourage you to check your inventory lists, so you need to pay attention.This is a rare occurance, however, dependant on character chosen rather than any particular oversight due to the game design.  There are plenty of new characters to purchase as well as three of the original six expansion packs already released.  Dice roll for me is depressingly unlucky (just as it always was for my board games) so i find the gameplay quite difficult.  Animations are colourful and the addition of runestones and customisable rules keeps the game interesting. You can even save your progress on multiple games and come back to them when you want.I highly recommend this game already and will love it even more when the Timescape expansion is added.

content:
y 21
												Nice game if you like games like snakes and ladders but with warrior and wizzard pieces instead of generic pawn pieces. There is very little to no strategy in this game, it is almost ENTIRELY down to dice rolls. You roll a dice and move here, roll another dice to see what happens, pick up an 'adventure' card which could be an item or enemy, then roll another dice to determine the outcome. It is about as 'strategic' as playing roulette or lottery. I'm not having a go at this game, it is an amusing way to pass time, but if you read that there is a strategy to winning this game it is not entirely correct.. unless by strategy you mean staying in one region of the board until you have enough items to progress to the next then so be it. I guess to some extent that would be considered a strategy. I have played this game for a couple of hours and it was amusing, but it was amusing in the way that snakes and ladders would be if you had beautifully crafted pieces available instead of generic pawn pieces and instead of there being only snakes there were dragons and goblins you had to deal with and instead of automatically sliding backwards down a snake you got to take a dice roll which can be modified by items you pick up to detemine what happens to you. I definately dont see myself investing a lot of time into this game but it is worth the investment if you are looking for an amusing 'filler in type of a game' that can easily pass an hour or so of your time when nothing else seems to tickle your fancy.

content:
, 2014
												Amazing game!I got the game in July 2014 on a sweat -50% season pass. BEST DECISION OF MY LIFE! The amount of content added to this game is epic. I am a huge fan of randomness and replay ability and this game is perfect! No two games are alike and you have a lot of options to customize the speed and difficulty of the game. You might not be a fan of dice games because too much luck is involved, honestly so am I! I rarely play dice games, but I feel that talisman has the perfect combination of luck-to-strategy ratio. I like to compare it to real life. In real life, no matter how cautious you are, no matter how safe your daily routine is, on a particularly unlucky day... you can die... at the prime of your life you can get hit by a car... you can go to the hospital for routine surgery and die on the table... Talisman is like that! One minute you are the terror of the board, banishing demons and slaying dragons with the flick of your wand or tap of your sword, the next minute you are a cursed toad, powerless and vulnerable. The other night I lost a game after a series of 3 unlucky dice rolls, I was in the lead on stats, two turns away from winning the game, next turn I was dead. The odds of me dyeing there were 0.4%. I wasn't even mad, that was amazing! Good things can happen as well. One game I was the underdog, a lowly merchant, unskilled in combat, unwise in magic. After gathering a small pose consisting of a gnome, a guide and a faery; and armed with only a Talisman and a four leaf clover. I managed to pick the lock on the portal of power, brave the forgotten depths of the lost mines, escape a vampire's domain (RIP followers), then defeat four lesser demons in combat, cross the valley of fire and finally arrive at the crown of command. There, I obtained the power to command death as my servant and send him to kill my enemies one by one! All this was achieved with beginner level stats. I had no chance to win by overtaking my enemies the safe way so I risked it all, and this time I won.I have no problem finding games online to play with strangers. It's more fun to play with friends. I regularly buy copies of Talisman when it's on sale (usually 1-2 euro for the base game) and gift them. The good thing is that my friends don't need the expansions to play with me, because in a multiplayer game if one person has all the expansions then the game is played with all of them. In my experience games with 3 players are the best. With 4 or more the game tends to last longer. Two player games are also fine.The rules of the game are easy on beginners. Even if it's a complex game, the rules come at you one at a time. You don't need to know what all the cards in the game do, because you will only draw one or two cards a turn usually and then just read those cards and see what happens! I remember when I first played Talisman, I had no idea what was happening... and that was great! I'm a dwarf in a fantasy world. I fight monsters, find treasure, and buy drinks at the tavern. My opponent is a troll who found a unicorn. The unicorn is smarter than he is...I could say a lot more about this game, it is simply amazing and lots of fun. It's well worth full price, if you are undecided, buy the base game on sale and play it online. You will not regret it!

												I do enjoy this game, both the actual board game and this port.Let me just say I wanted to say I recommend it, yet also don't.Unfortunately I feel like the game (when played against bots) is geared to the bots,rolls seem to always be low for me, I've counted maybe five rolls of 6 in all games I've played,and the bots always seem to get high rolls with low rolls against them, without fail. Yeah, but I still like the game. And since I got it as a gift from a friend,I feel even more inclined to not look too harshly on the mistakes.Take a chance, roll the die, and see if you buy Talisman.

content:
er 27, 2014
												Classic game brought to computer life.  Considering the table game is over $40, this is a bargain!For those of you who try to compare this game to something like Hearthstone, all I can say is "Don't" because that is apples to oranges. All the strategy comes from what the cards give you, how well the dice treats you and how badly it treats your fellow players. In Hearthstone, unless you are playing with a starter deck, the strategy is the deck building and praying you get the cards you need out in time. Not unlike MtG. But with Talisman, you only have your class' benefits/drawbacks and MAYBE your choice of Runestones if you opted for that DLC. After that, you just have to watch the game unfold and as another reviewer put it, prepare for some serious "risk management". Also, this game has no time limit unless you set one.  Unless you set it up for sudden death (120 turns or less), all I can say is this party can go all night, so have 4 six-packs and a couple bottles of wine to enjoy with this game. I played one game, 3 players and 1 AI and each player, including the AI, each had a major setback and the game took 3 hours to conclude. Might want to order out when playing this game. ALSO, for new players, turn off the timer so you can learn the cards. Had that issue when entering the Warlocks area, he offers 6 or so quests but the timer can time out while you are still reading the second card. This isn't chess. Its on by default, so check setting and turn it off because when it times out, you skip your turn.With that said, the more real players, the better. The AI isn't always perfect and when an AI tries to use some spells or magic items, it can sometimes throw the game for a loop. I have only had this game actually crash TWICE in nearly 2 years I've owned it and only required a reboot from that once. Loops happen a little more often in which case you have to alt-tab out to desktop and shut down the program manually with Task Manager. But it is still worth the occassional headache.

content:
0, 2015
												Okay, right off the bat, this is an awesome game to play! So much fun to level up your character, gaining strength and craft to fight enemies with. The object of the game is to reach "the crown of command" in the center of the board. However this is not so simple. You will have to go on different quests throughout the game to gain an object known as a "Talisman" to get the various places on the board. You will need one as you travel from the middle region of the board to the center region. However many things could happen between getting one and getting through to the center region. A player could fight you and kill you. A witch, bear or demon could spawn on you and destroy powerful or useful items you're carrying. The worst? Being turned into a toad. This is where all your items are dropped in the space you have turned into the toad. While playing as a toad, other players can pick up your items. It's a very challenging game and extremely time consuming. The 8 hours i have played.. 6 of them is just one full game of talisman, where unfortunately i did not win! I have the actual board game too and the digital version helped me learn it better as it gives you tutorials on your playthrough. Of course these can be turned off! If you are a fan of fantasy, board games and strategy then this one is definately for you! For what it is, i give it an 8/10. The game itself is excellent, but as i say you need a LOT of time spare if you're wanting to finish a game!

												If you like board games then this game is great.  You'll want to get DLC at least to Dungeon to make it more replayable.  You do not need humans to play and the AI isn't that bad, except for their use of spells.  Spells aren't utilized very well by AI.  It will take time to learn the "When can I cast this system."  Spells do not have a natural or intuitive system for casting.  Even after 10-15 games you can still not cast them at right times always. Lots of options for which DLC to use each game and what parts of each can be used.  Know games can take 30 minutes to 3 hours to win.  What character you play and what cards you and the others get make a huge difference in the time involved.

content:
ber 12, 2015
												Love this game. Love it! I'm a board game/TTRPG junkie (multi-time Gen Con attendee). There's a ton of content here, and the game is fun and challenging at the same time. It's nice to be able to just jump into the digital edition without setup, and even with some AI that's not TOO bad. It does make a few boneheaded mistakes though.For instance I usually play with random characters against 3 AI. I had the Troll. I killed one of the other characters and forgot to loot ALL the items (my own fault, hit the button to quick) and the Devil's Minion CPU player swooped in and grabbed it all including the follower that reduces the Peril of Plane's requirements by 1 die. OMG. The Devil's Minion made to the the Crown of Command, because he made it there so early he only had 5 STR and 6 CRA. I got EXTREMELY lucky and grabbed the poltergiest as a follower on the right side of the outer region of the board. Along there was "The healer with 2 free heals " (thankfully I got turned to Good along the way!) and "The Shrine", next to them was the Forest. So since I could only move one space it was great that I could keep moving back and forth between these spaces healing myself and trying to bump up my craft at the Forest. I also had spells of one Counterspell, one Random, and one Temporal Warp. I was going to use the Temporal Warp when I finally started making my run to the Crown! I made a huge mistake by going into the Village and not realizing it ditched the Poltergiest! OH NO! Since I had 10 STR and 5 CRA, I decided to make a run for it. The Devil's Minion rolled BADLY on quite a few Crown spells. I luckily made my way all the way to the Crown with 11 STR from figting one monster along the way and cashing some in. So the Devil's Minion had 5 lives, I had 4. But I definitely had the upper hand from a mathematical standpoint. So what does the Devil's Minion do when he fights me, he picks STR!! WHAT IN THE. I was afraid it was going to be a race to 0 to see who could roll luck (he COULDN'T beat me in STR 11 vs 5, but he had a chance in CRA 5 vs 6). So I whittled him down to 1 health, and THEN he finally lets loose with a CRA attack and actually wins. I beat him the next turn.This is what I mean by the AI makes some poor decisions. What should have been a nail-biter, ended up being a big WHA? What is he doing?! Still love the game!!
